I try to squeeze in dplyr::n_distinct() to my basic intro.  In my experience mostly useful for data checking/qaqc (i.e., becoming one with your dataset).
Yes! Super helpful. I currently use skimr to give students an overview, but that's super helpful in giving single variable summaries.
Why would you want students who are just learning r to write about some obscure function?

The point is for them to learn on their own and teach others. These aren't obscure functions, they're just lesser known ones. ; ; I can't teach them everything, so the more I can teach the meta-learning, the better they will be off in the future.
I use forcats all the time. It's especially helpful in ggplot when reordering an axis.
Definitely! {forcats} has so many useful functions.

tidyr::fill() - extremely useful when creating a usable dataset out of a spreadsheet originally built for data entry, in which redundant informations are only reported once at the beginning of the group they refer to, rather than in every row as needed for the analysis.

tidyr::fill() is the one that I find especially useful, for all those imported Excel files with row headings that are merged. Always assumed it existed, but didn't know its name until a colleague introduced us.

When you don't teach case_when, students will go years nesting ifelse like absolute chumps! Alternatively, to relabel discrete data I like to left_join with a crosswalk table so the associations are not hardcoded in the script.

One more and then I'll shut up ðŸ˜.  sf is not part of the tidyverse, but it might as well be.  Spatial file processing that is completely seamless with dplyr, ggplot, etc.  I make all my maps with it these days.; And finally, the tidy() function from broom.
Yes, {sf} is fantastic! Makes complicated spatial queries and joins much easier.
make_valid() is the sf magic wand that solves random polygon slivers that often exist in data.

do you teach tidyverse directly or base r first?

I teach just enough base R for them to understand vectors, functions, and data.frames. ; ; You can see the previous class here: https://t.co/4WweuqMSl8; ; The rest is mostly tidyverse, except for the cases when they will encounter base-R a lot.

I know this is probably controversial, but my goal is to get them up and working usefully as quickly as possible, rather than teach a standard programming course, which you have to learn a lot of things before you do something useful.
